text: Mutual regulation of the transcriptional activator NF-kappa B and its inhibitor , <extra_id_0> I kappa B-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

The NK-kappa B transcription factor complex is sequestered in the cytoplasm by the inhibitory protein <extra_id_0> I kappa B-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> MAD-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .
Various cellular stimuli relieve this inhibition by mechanisms largely unknown , leading to NF-kappa B nuclear localization and transactivation of its target genes .

It is demonstrated here with human T lymphocytes and monocytes that different stimuli , including <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate , cause rapid degradation of <extra_id_0> I kappa B-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , with concomitant activation of NF-kappa B , followed by a dramatic increase in <extra_id_0> I kappa B-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA and protein synthesis .

Transfection studies reveal that the <extra_id_0> I kappa B-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA and the encoded protein are potently induced by NF-kappa B and by homodimers of <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and of <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

We propose a model in which NF-kappa B and <extra_id_0> I kappa B-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mutually regulate each other in a cycle : saturating amounts of the inhibitory <extra_id_0> I kappa B-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein are destroyed upon stimulation , allowing rapid activation of NF-kappa B . Subsequently , <extra_id_0> I kappa B-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA and protein levels are quickly induced by the activated NF-kappa B .
This resurgence of <extra_id_0> I kappa B-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein acts to restore an equilibrium in which NF-kappa B is again inhibited .
